channel.title: The Sydney Morning Herald National Headlines
channel.description: The top National headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit http://www.smh.com.au.

item.title: International markets roundup
item.description: News from the world’s major stock markets

item.title: Digger involved in incident in Afghanistan
item.description: There's been another operational incident involving an Australian soldier in Afghanistan, with details to be released shortly.

item.title: $A follows euro stocks higher
item.description: The Australian dollar is higher after European stock markets rallied overnight.

item.title: Australian market preview
item.description: A preview of the Australian sharemarket.

item.title: Cutting a deal
item.description: Tony Mokbel's sentencing on major drugs charges will skirt his links to several underworld murders.

item.title: Albury woman linked to Mexican bombings
item.description: An Albury woman has been linked to bombings carried out by a Mexican anarchist group.

item.title: The ghost ships that creep across the blue
item.description: Some time on Sunday night, 37 men and two boys appeared from the Indian Ocean.

item.title: Gillard snub to African Union
item.description: Prime Minister knocks back Malawi President's invitation to top level regional summit.

item.title: PM rejects suggestion of leadership trouble
item.description: Julia Gillard dismisses idea that poor poll results will add to pressure.

item.title: Power bills to include price rise 'facts'
item.description: Utility companies to enclose flyers meant to deflect anger over rising electricity prices.

item.title: Landfills waste no time in dumping carbon price on their customers
item.description: LANDFILLS have pushed up gate fees by more than 20 per cent as the carbon tax and the state's waste levy combine to blow out the cost of dumping rubbish.

item.title: Rebuff to Africa may backfire on Gillard in UN vote
item.description: FOR months Australian diplomats lobbied African leaders to give Julia Gillard a starring role at a top-level regional summit and spruik Australia's campaign for a seat on the United Nations Security Council - only for the Prime Minister to knock back the invitation when it came.

item.title: Carr opines that Julian Assange is of little interest to the US by this time
item.description: Foreign Minister Bob Carr is confident the US will not seek to extradite Julian Assange.

item.title: Jailed lawyer faces inquiry into conduct after release is secured in Libya
item.description: THE Australian lawyer Melinda Taylor and her three fellow International Criminal Court (ICC) colleagues are still likely to face an internal ICC inquiry into allegations raised by Libyan authorities should they be released overnight.

item.title: No limit to state jobs cleanout
item.description: A CONFIDENTIAL Treasury memo reveals there is no cap on the number of public sector redundancies in NSW, paving the way for job cuts extending beyond the 10,000 announced in the state budget.

item.title: Scientology creepy, maybe evil, says Murdoch
item.description: ITS devotees may include some of Hollywood's biggest box office earners. But when Scientology was raised as a possible cause for the break-up of Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes, Rupert Murdoch could not resist commenting.

item.title: SBY talks unlikely to yield smuggling solution
item.description: THE government is playing down any impact on people smuggling that may be achieved from today's meeting between the Prime Minister, Julia Gillard, and the Indonesian President, Susilo Bambang Yudhoyono.

item.title: So far it's not so good for the PM but at least …
item.description: THE Prime Minister has cautioned it will take months for voters to shed their fears of the carbon tax as Labor MPs increasingly question whether the government's poll situation can be reversed.

item.title: Women using IVF to screen out cancer
item.description: FERTILE women with genes that predispose them to breast and ovarian cancer are using IVF to select embryos without the genes so their children are free of the distress they cause.

item.title: All bets on Reserve to stay its hand
item.description: THE Reserve Bank's board is considered to be certain to sit on its hands today for the first time in three months amid signs that its previous rate cuts are stabilising property prices.

item.title: Bureau of Statistics admits blundering on jobless figures
item.description: THE Australian Bureau of Statistics has got the official employment figures wrong, and the bureau says it will not correct them because it would cost too much money.

item.title: For Mokbel, minimum sentence will make life tolerable
item.description: The drug dealer vigorously fought charges against him for a reason, writes John Silvester.

item.title: Harvey Norman floors koalas, says green group
item.description: THE retail giant Harvey Norman has been accused of selling flooring made from native forests in NSW where koalas face extinction following an investigation by environmental activists who tracked timber harvested in prime koala habitat.

item.title: Tony Mokbel faces long prison term
item.description: The last chapter in the colourful criminal case of Tony Mokbel will be played out in court when he is sentenced.

item.title: IVF couples pick cancer-free genes
item.description: IVF couples with genes predisposed to cancer are picking embryos free of such issues in what ethicists fear is a move to designer babies.

item.title: Flu downs GetUp boss on live TV
item.description: GetUp director Simon Sheikh was recovering from a bout of flu when he collapsed on live television, it has emerged.

item.title: Arrest over death boat
item.description: Authorities in Indonesia have arrested a man suspected of organising the asylum-seeker boat that sank en route to Australia last month, killing about 90 people.

item.title: NSW police travel for Stenberg extradition
item.description: NSW detectives are expected to fly to Darwin on Tuesday to bring back accused killer Jonathon Stenberg.

item.title: Flu downs GetUp! boss on live TV
item.description: GetUp! director Simon Sheikh was recovering from a bout of influenza when he collapsed on live TV.

item.title: Panellist collapses on Q&A
item.description: The head of GetUp!, Simon Sheikh, collapsed on live television last night.

item.title: Canberra extend NRL streak over Dragons
item.description: Canberra have extended their 12-year winning streak at home over St George Illawarra with a comeback 22-18 victory on Monday.

item.title: Australia plans for cleaner economy: Swan
item.description: Wayne Swan says it's important Australia has an economy substantially powered by renewable energy and that the carbon tax is helping achieve that end.

item.title: Man arrested over deadly voyage
item.description: Authorities in Indonesia arrested a man suspected of organising the asylum-seeker boat that sank en route to Australia last month, killing about 90 people.

item.title: Online sharing reduces loneliness among the aged
item.description: Sharing photos online using iPads can reduce loneliness in elderly people who are socially isolated, a new study has found.

item.title: Asylum seeker numbers rising fast
item.description: A SURGE in the number of Sri Lankan asylum seekers reaching Australia by boat over the past three weeks – treble the number that arrived over all of last year – has seen arrival numbers surpass 2009, when the country was gripped by brutal civil war.

item.title: Family awaits lawyer's release in Libya
item.description: Australian lawyer Melinda Taylor's parents say they're grateful for the Australian government's support while their daughter has been held in Libya.

item.title: MP Craig Emerson sings for Whyalla
item.description: Craig Emerson became a Twitter trend after a singing performance that rivalled neither Peter Garrett nor Pavarotti.

item.title: Swans pair lifting for run home: Longmire
item.description: Swans coach John Longmire expects key players Adam Goodes and Shane Mumford to be fresh for the back end of the season.

item.title: Origin schedule frustrates Titans coach
item.description: Gold Coast coach John Cartwright has renewed calls for stand-alone Origins after venting his frustration over the uncertainty it creates.

item.title: Hawks won't rush Franklin back
item.description: Hawthorn say they will ease Lance Franklin back into training midweek, lengthening the odds of the star forward playing in their AFL clash with GWS.

item.title: Bronco Reed sidelined with broken leg
item.description: Broncos centre Jack Reed will miss at least a month of NRL after breaking his leg against Cronulla.

item.title: Petrol falls to 17-month low
item.description: Petrol prices are tipped to drop by four cents a litre in the next seven to 10 days after sliding to a 17-month low in the past week, an economist says.

item.title: Europe gives RBA reason to hold rates
item.description: A deal to ease pressures in the eurozone will give Australia's Reserve Bank another reason to sit on rates at its monthly meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: Crows confused over Taylor Walker's ban
item.description: Adelaide captain Nathan van Berlo says the three-game ban to teammate Taylor Walker for a dangerous tackle is confusing for the AFL competition.

item.title: Reds hungry to repeat Super success
item.description: Queensland won't be satisfied with making the Super Rugby playoffs and believe they can defend their title by hitting their straps in the next month.

item.title: Carbon tax business backers criticised
item.description: The federal government will ride out the negativity surrounding its carbon tax, despite getting support from some major businesses.

item.title: Ashby seeks to delay Slipper response
item.description: James Ashby has filed an application seeking to delay filing a response to the accusations made against him until the sexual harrassment case is in court.

item.title: Digger's dog 'Quake' killed in firefight
item.description: An Australian soldier has been wounded and a "much-loved" military dog killed during a firefight with insurgents in Afghanistan.

item.title: High wages another blow to business
item.description: The Dun & Bradstreet National Business Expectations Survey for June shows pessimism among manufacturers and retailers alike.

item.title: Taylor Walker faces three-match suspension
item.description: Adelaide's Taylor Walker looks set for three matches on the AFL sidelines over his spear tackle following match review panel findings on Monday.

item.title: Arrium positive about steel earnings
item.description: OneSteel relaunches as Arrium and says its steel operations are on track to produce a positive earnings result for the second half of the financial year.

item.title: Tigers playing for form, not NRL ladder
item.description: Wests Tigers centre Chris Lawrence says his side needs to worry about finding form rather than where they can finish in the NRL top eight.

item.title: Drug lord Mokbel faces long prison term
item.description: The final chapter in the Tony Mokbel saga will play out on Tuesday when he is sentenced in a Melbourne court.

item.title: Positive injury diagnosis for GWS duo
item.description: GWS veteran Luke Power will miss two matches with rib cartilage damage, while young gun Dylan Shiel will be sidelined for 3-4 matches with a footy injury.

item.title: Bernard Foley set to pull strings for Tahs
item.description: Exciting young NSW Waratahs back Bernard Foley believes a new ballplaying partnership will add an extra spark to the side.

item.title: Lend Lease shares rise more than 5%
item.description: Lend Lease shares rose by more than five per cent after the developer announced it expected a modest profit rise.

item.title: Sadler faces court over Murdoch interview
item.description: Seven Network journalist Rahni Sadler will face court next month accused of illegally communicating with a prisoner but charges against the broadcaster have been withdrawn.

item.title: Foreign Defence shop aids exporters
item.description: A one-stop-shop will allow Australian defence manufacturers to export their wares - including Fyshwick's CEA Technologies.

item.title: Botha won't rule Redbacks with iron fist
item.description: South African spinner Johan Botha says he won't completely overhaul South Australian cricket is his new role as Redbacks captain.

item.title: Mainstream firms unhappy with carbon tax
item.description: The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry says mainstream small business is unhappy with the carbon tax.

item.title: Beale remains in doubt for Rebels tour
item.description: Neither Kurtley Beale nor fellow Wallabies star James O'Connor are among the 25-player Melbourne Rebels squad which has flown to South Africa.

item.title: Have you seen Daniel, Shane or Nicholas?
item.description: Two fathers who have not seen or heard from their young children for months are making public pleas for help, with the boys believed to be with their mothers.

item.title: David Jones shares enter trading halt
item.description: Shares in troubled department store chain David Jones have been placed in a trading halt ahead of an announcement by the company.

item.title: Anti-smuggling efforts underappreciated
item.description: Indonesia and Australia have had successes in the fight against people smugglers, Defence Minister Stephen Smith says.

item.title: Army buying extra 214 Bushmaster vehicles
item.description: Defence is purchasing another 214 Australian-made Bushmaster armoured vehicles, bringing the army's fleet to about 1000.

item.title: Labor could lose NSW by-election: Daley
item.description: NSW Labor frontbencher Michael Daley says the ALP could lose former premier Kristina Keneally's seat of Heffron in a by-election.

item.title: Graham, Smith set to escape NRL bans
item.description: Cronulla's Wade Graham and Jeremy Smith look set to play the Sydney Roosters next week despite attracting charges from the NRL match review committee.

item.title: Ratten will be here next year: Gibbs
item.description: Carlton midfielder turned defender Bryce Gibbs has backed besieged coach Brett Ratten as the Blues plummet to 10th with six losses from seven games.

item.title: Rate cuts push up home prices
item.description: Recent interest cuts have helped reverse the recent slump in home prices, a new survey shows.

item.title: Online spending up 18 points in May
item.description: Australian online retail sales have posted moderate growth in May compared to the previous month.

item.title: Covic, Haliti sign with A-League newcomers
item.description: The Western Sydney Wanderers say pride in their jersey will be a key ingredient in their inaugural A-League season.

item.title: Poll results 'electoral justice': Abbott
item.description: Tony Abbott says the Australian public is "punishing" the federal government for its lies.

item.title: Manufacturing sector contracted in June
item.description: Australia's manufacturing sector contracted in June, but at a slower pace than in May

item.title: NSW still haunted by 2011 false start
item.description: NSW assistant coach Trent Barrett says the Blues must get off to a better start on Wednesday than they did when the series was on the line last year.

item.title: Queensland will test Carney's nerve
item.description: Queensland will apply the blowtorch early to inexperienced NSW five-eighth Todd Carney to see if he cracks under pressure in Wednesday night's Origin III.

item.title: Beheading case: move to extradite Stenberg
item.description: A man accused of a grisly murder in NSW is awaiting an extradition hearing in a Darwin court.

item.title: Inflation rate lowest since GFC
item.description: Australia's inflation rate has dropped to its slowest pace since the global financial crisis, a survey shows

item.title: Govt welcomes Taylor's likely release
item.description: The federal government has welcomed news Libyan authorities look set to release Australian lawyer Melinda Taylor.

item.title: Simpsons co-creator backs anti-whaling bid
item.description: A co-creator of The Sim-psons has promised to underwrite the cost of a fourth, potentially game-changing, ship for Sea Shepherd's Antarctic anti-whaling campaign.

item.title: Bonds weaker on EU meeting result
item.description: The Australian bond market is weaker on generally positive sentiment following a summit of European leaders.

item.title: We'll cut emissions without tax: Abbott
item.description: Tony Abbott is campaigning hard to convince people the carbon tax will be all financial pain and no environmental gain.

item.title: Gillard, SBY get ready for hard talks
item.description: Bilateral talks between Australia and Indonesia will involve discussions about hard issues like terrorism, drugs and people smuggling.

item.title: Commodities markets summary
item.description: Commodities news from around the world

item.title: Aust stocks close higher
item.description: The Australian sharemarket has closed higher in the wake of the European Union summit, but David Jones has slumped after a takeover proposal was withdrawn.

item.title: Govt seeks return of health overpayments
item.description: Almost 50,000 letters documenting $89.5 million in Queensland Health overpayments will begin arriving, ending the moratorium.

item.title: Stocks to watch at close on Monday
item.description: Stocks of interest on the Australian Securities Exchange at close on Monday

item.title: International markets roundup
item.description: News from the world’s major stock markets

item.title: Summit sentiment keeps $A high
item.description: The Australian dollar continues to trade strongly following developments from a summit of European leaders, which ended on Friday.

item.title: Cocos centre upgraded to cater for asylum seekers
item.description: AUSTRALIAN authorities are rushing to upgrade quarantine facilities at the remote Cocos Islands, confirming fears that people smugglers from Sri Lanka and southern India have chosen the island group as a new frontier in the asylum seeker trade.

item.title: Labor the loser in blame game over boats deadlock
item.description: THE government has borne the brunt of the blame for last week's policy deadlock on asylum seekers, while the Coalition and the Greens, who combined to block legislation in the Senate, come equal second.

item.title: Low expectations are easily met
item.description: WHAT does it say about a country when nearly 90 per cent of the people's hopes of their leaders are hugely disappointed on an important matter, yet the leaders' approval ratings do not budge?

item.title: US senator calls to prosecute Assange
item.description: THE head of the US Senate's powerful intelligence oversight committee has renewed calls for Julian Assange to be prosecuted for espionage.

item.title: As a new era dawns, the leaders make their cases
item.description: THE Opposition Leader, Tony Abbott, declared yesterday that the ''campaign is now on'' as the Gillard government began the tough job of selling its carbon tax, the biggest economic reform the country has seen since the GST.

item.title: Injured workers spied on by transport giant Toll
item.description: Transport company using private investigators to follow staff who take leave to recover from workplace injuries.

item.title: Businesses raise prices to pass on new costs
item.description: FOUR in 10 businesses in manufacturing, services and construction plan to raise their prices immediately in response to the carbon tax, a survey has found.

item.title: Climate change a hoax, Jones tells tax protesters
item.description: THE world didn't end yesterday but Australian democracy died, according to protesters who gathered to make their voices heard in opposition to the carbon price.

item.title: Court threat for non-compliance by emitters
item.description: THE chairwoman of the Clean Energy Regulator has warned that she is prepared to go to court to ensure the approximately 300 biggest greenhouse gas emitters, mostly businesses and councils, meet their obligations under the carbon tax legislation.

item.title: Now to see if the fuss fades away or keeps burning
item.description: THE debate over carbon pricing now shifts gear. Two questions are likely to dominate the coming weeks.

item.title: Fugitive caught in bush
item.description: Alleged killer in custody after Northern Territory police capture heavily armed fugitive hiding in bushland.

item.title: Justice fight may go on
item.description: Michael Chamberlain considers campaign calling for national inquiry into administration of justice.
